title-part.text: HOT GAS OR COMBUSTION-PRODUCT POSITIVE-DISPLACEMENT ENGINE PLANTS

reference.text: steam engine plants, special vapour plants, plants operating on either hot gas or combustion-product gases together with other fluid F01K; gas-turbine plants F02C; jet-propulsion plants F02K

title-part.text: USE OF WASTE HEAT OF COMBUSTION ENGINES

note.note-paragraph: Attention is drawn to the notes preceding class F01.

reference.text: positive-displacement engine plants characterised by the working gas being generated by combustion in the plant F02G3/00

title-part.text: the engine being operated by expansion and contraction of a mass of working gas which is heated and colled in one of a plurality of constantly communicating expansible chambers, e.g. Stirling cycle type engine

CPC-specific-text.text: the engine being of the free piston type

title-part.text: having at least two working members, e.g. pistons, delivering power output

CPC-specific-text.text: Engine plants with combined cycles, e.g. Vuilleumier

title-part.text: by varying the heating or cooling
by varying the rate of flow or quantity of the working gas
Positive-displacement engine plants characterised by the working gas being generated by combustion in the plant
Profiting from waste heat of combustion engines, not otherwise provided for
Profiting from waste heat of exhaust gases
in combination with other waste heat from combustion engines
Ericsson-type engines having open regenerative cycles controlled by valves
having gas actuated valves, e.g. "Bush engines"
having mechanically actuated valves, e.g. "Gifford" or "McMahon engines"
having a single piston regenerative displacer attached to the piston, e.g. "Gifford-McMahon" engines
having two pistons and reverse flow regenerators
Stirling type engines having closed regenerative thermodynamic cycles with flow controlled by volume changes
having pistons and displacers in the same cylinder
each having a single free piston, e.g. "Beale engines"
having their pistons and displacers each in separate cylinders
Regenerative displacers having parallel cylinder, e.g. "Lauberau" or "Schwartzkopff" engines
Regenerative displacers having their cylinders at right angle, e.g. "Robinson" engines
External regenerators having parallel cylinders, e.g. "Heinrici" engines
of rotary cylinder type, e.g. "Finkelstein" engines
having interconnecting adjacent cylinders constituting a single system, e.g. "Rinia" engines
having two-cylinder twin systems, with compression in one cylinder and expansion in the other cylinder for each of the twin systems, e.g. "Finkelstein" engines
Beau de Rochas constant volume cycles
Ringbom engines, the displacement of the free displacer being obtained by expansion of the heated gas and the weight of the piston
by catalytic conversion, i.e. flameless oxydation
Recuperating heat from exhaust gases of combustion engines and heat from cooling circuits
Recuperating heat from exhaust gases of combustion engines and heat from lubrication circuits
Shells, e.g. a sealed or sealing shell for a Stirling engine
the displacer being driven by a four-bar mechanism, e.g. a rhombic mechanism
Medical applications, e.g. for prosthesis or artificial hearts
Engines characterised by the use of a particular power transfer medium, e.g. Helium
